The Conference had unddr consideration.the following recommendation of the Committee in regardto the ppioe of wheat:-That an announcement should be made to the'farmers on behalf of the Government in thefollowing termsIt Is hoped that before the-Autumn pf 1921the importation and control of the prioeof wheat by the Government will have ceased,and that farmers will secure the benefit ofa free market at world's prices.So long as whaat is still controlled, and thereby deprived of a free market, the con-,trolled price of homo-grown wheat of soundVmilling quality, harvested in 1921, will bothe average (c.i.f.) price, for the.twelvemonths ending August 31st, 1921, of imported wheat of similar or comparable quality, pro-vided that the price, so paid to the home-grower shall not exceed 100/- per quarterof 504-lbs. It was stated that farmers would he guaranteeda minimum price for wheat in the Bill promised bythePrime Minister and now under consideration by the ministry of Agriculture. The present proposals didnot give a minimum but guaranteed that the Governmentwould not so exercise their control of wheat as togive to the farmers less than 100/- per quarter whenthe.^varaKa.marjiet urice of imported wheat, o.i.f.was at or above that figure. Some such announcement was necessary in order to carry out the policy of theMinistry of Agriculture to increase the arable area in this country, and to prevent a widespread laying down of land to grass, which was already imminent.Some discussion took place as to whether theproposals of the Committee went far enough. It wassuggested that, Inasmuch as the increased price wouldnot take effect until the harvest of.1921, it would beunjust to those farmers who at considerable sacrificehad grown wheat on their land for the harvest 19 20and who would not receive the benefit of the higher price, while those farmers who did not sow wheat until next winter "rould reap the full benefit. Emphasis was laid on the fact that farmers who complied with therequirements of the law are now compelled to sell the whole of their wheat at the Government price and topay a higher'price themselves for food-stuffs for theircattle.In reply to the suggestion that farmers ought not to be- robbed of the benefit of a free market, andshould be ia a position to obtain as much for wheatas the farmers in foreign countries, it was pointed outthat a large part of the high prioe paid for foreignwheat was caused by exchange, insurance, and freight, and that, in many cases, the foreign farmer had received,or was actually receiving, leys per quarter than Britishfarmers. The justification for -limiting the maximum price to 100/- was that our farmers ought not to been abled to make an advantage out of the world shortage-of wheat, and must expect tc have their profitsrestricted in the same wsy as coal &rid shipping profits.Some discussion took place as to whether itwould not be possible to extend the increased price to the 1920 harvest, but it was pointed out that, on theone hand, 85fo of the wheat was already sown so that noincreased acreage would be obtained.s while, on the otherhand, if the new price were to come into operation as early as the Autumn of this year, the result would be to cause the immediate holding up of all grain from the 1919harvest that had not already been threshed.The Conference agreed:-to approve an immediate announcement by the Minister of Agriculture in theterms of the formula recommended bythe Committee.The Conference agreedto approve the following furtherrecommendations of the Committeeon Food Control:(iii) Butter. BRADBURY.Treasury Chambers,Whitehall,S.W.1.February 26th, 1920.My dear Bradbury,I enclose for your confidential information amemorandum?of the General Staff circulated to the Cabinetby Mr. Churchill and a note x upon it by myself.- these papers were yesterday considered by the Cabinet. they thought it undesirable that I should give you any formalinstructions on the subject or that you should raise it with your colleagues on express instructions from your government,. At the same time they agreed with the view expressed by the General Staff as to the desirability inthe interests of the Allied Governments of maintaining theauthority of the present German Government in preference to the only possible alternatives, and they agreed further in viewing with considerable anxiety the present economic position of Germany and,the stagnation of her industrial life.The provision of article 235 of the Treaty whichcontemplates that Germany shall be allowed out of her firstpayment such supplies of food and raw materials as may beconsidered necessary to enable her to meet her obligationsfqr reparation was inserted in order to provide a remedy for this state of things,, and they wished me to inform youpersonally that they are quite prepared for and will readilyapprove any arrangements which you and your colleagues onthe Reparation Commission may make for the restorationcf-German industry in pursuance of this article. they attach great importance to the- resumption of german economic life and production not only on-political groundsbut as being essential to. the ability of Germany to meetthe just claims of the Allies upon her.Yours sincerely,(Sdo) AUSTEN CHAMBERLAIN.I CP.63$.X CP.671.John Bradbury, G C B .
